the video showed for a short time a "non-solvable" pattern of horizontal bars of all colors, a special case. the sum of any normal circle would be 0 as the path can only be symmetrical. the sum of a "horizontal" circle touching horizontal infinity would be zero as it spans only the same color. but a "vertical" circle touching infinity would have an infinitely high sum. understanding the result would mean there can be zeros and thus solutions. with a bit of imagination they could be imagined at the left and right ends of the plane - infinity is no place that you will ever be able to go, but the pattern hints for it. imaginating the surface being colored and the left and right infinity ends being pulled together by a transformation (or just compacted by two little ropes) to shape a surface that looks like an open eye with lids... we end up with the color rays pointing all to the left and right infinity point. having a vertical line doing a circle to the upper and lower ends still hints for a zero on both the left and the right half. further transforming this eye-lid surface into a volumetric figure, a sphere by connecting the upper and lower edge together will bring up a nice colorful striped ball with two poles on the left and right and the vertical line beeing again a circle. so the whole figure shows it quite nicely how to even get an understanding of infinity still being a valid solution to expect and how to deal with it for the 2D functional case. by the way it also allows to track down solutions in non-infinity space. and it finally shows that if there is one solution on one side of the circle then another solution on the other side is unavoidable. If you wanted to implement this algorithm, you could find the winding number of a curve using a complex integral.

Let C be a curve in the input space (the rectangles in the video) which is defined by the differentiable complex function z(t) on the interval t between a and b (so plugging t values in [a,b] into z(t) draws out the curve C), and f(w) be the differentiable function whose zeroes are sought.

The winding number of f(C) is given by the integral of [f’(z(t)) * z’(t)] / [2πi * f(z(t))] dt from a to b

If z(t) is piecewise (like for a rectangle,) you would add up the winding numbers for each piece (each side.)

Another potentially helpful thing: given two complex numbers v and w, one parameterization of the line from v to w is z(t) = (1-t)*v + t*w for t in [0,1].

At 21:00 you find a zero on the boundary of two regions - but you grey them out while continuing in the other two regions. Either your algorithm is looking for any zero, in which case it should stop as soon as you find this one, or it's looking for all of them, in which case greying out the regions is a mistake because you don't know there are no zeros in their interiors.

There's another issue - you motivate the algorithm by saying you want to compute the function on as few inputs as possible, but your animations suggest you want to compute the function on the boundaries of regions, which (being closed curves) contain infinitely many points. In practice you can only do this for finitely many points, so you can't generally be sure that a 0.4 followed by a 0.41 really was a small clockwise winding rather than a large anticlockwise winding. For this you need an upper bound on the gradient.

Of course, the main point of the video was to explain two-dimensional functions, winding numbers, and the meta-topic - not to explain a particular algorithm for finding zeros. So both of these bugs are justifiable, but then you shouldn't say at 19:10 that the algorithm has no bugs.
